description: Part of the “Das Schwarze Auge Brettspiel” (The Dark Eye Boardgame) line. (The Way to Draconia) is a card/board game  who each control a well-known adventuring group / race. Each race is comprised of typical RPG-style heroes. Each hero has special abilities that let him get ahead in the game. The game ends as soon as a hero reaches the goal space in Drakonia. The goal of the game is to move your heroes as far along the path as possible. Multiple cards in hand let the heroes slowly but surely move forward on the difficult path. Being with your own group naturally makes things move more quickly, but careful, other heroes might block your path. And faster than you’d like, a hero might find himself injured on the side of the road or sent back to the start.

Each player gets 7 cards. The first who finishes his hand wins the game. But: there aren't any rules yet which tell you which card can be played onto which other card. When it's a players turn, he plays a card, or draws a card and makes a new rule before he plays one card. So you have to remember the rules set by the players to finish your hand and win the game. It's not as easy as it sounds, why do you think it's called AAARGH !?
Rules are printed in English, German and Dutch. The box contains 50 playing cards.

This game is created in Singapore by a training consultant.

(From the website):
Alpha-Plus Training has developed a learning tool, the Zeros-to-Heros Entrepreneurship board game that can ignite your enterprising spirit!

Be Your Own Boss & Achieve Business Success!
You start the game as an employee with ZERO capital and ZERO understanding of business. Take the exciting path to become your OWN BOSS and see whether you survive or become an entrepreneurial HERO.

The world’s 1st board game that engages the enterprising spirit that is based on a robust framework which enables the enterprising spirit.

The Sonic X Trading Card Game is a collectible card game based on the Sonic X cartoon series, which is - in turn - based on SEGA's Sonic the Hedgehog video game franchise. In the game, players play cards into a grid in order to be the first player to capture three Chaos Emeralds.

From Rules:
For the Parent/Teacher
Explore India is a challenging and enjoyable game that rouses and develops the exploratory instincts inherent in every child.  While the child plays the game, he/she explores India as well as her neighbourhood.  He learns the basics of Geography.  He also learns the basic skills that are needed  to read and understand any map.  This action-oriented game makes the child realize that exploring India can be a rewarding as well as a pleasant experience.

The object of the game is to arrange four, differently  colored, plastic piglets (red, yellow, blue, and green) in a row so the new order is the same as a player's card. When a match is obtained a player may discard and try to match the next card on the following turn. The first player to discard all of his cards is the winner. No reading or counting required. Ages 7 and up.

A geography card game which allows a world map to be built in hundreds of different way. 
Each player adds a card from his hand to the map on the board. If a player cannot add to the map he draws a card. Game ends when one player runs out of cards.

Simple racing-gamble game using "Mexican live jumping bean."
Players are trainers of the jumping beans.  Players' love and body temperature vitalize a bug (laspeyresia saltitans) in its larva form (living inside the bean) and make it jump!  The owner of the first bean reaching the destination ovals that surrounds the starting circle wins.
The Beans (from the information card)
"The Mexican jumping beans (laspeyresia saltitans) come from the mountains in the states of Sonora and Sinaloa, Mexico.  They can be found in an area that is 30 miles by 100 miles where the host plants (sebastiana pavoniana) grows.  In the Spring, the moths emerge from last years beans and deposit the eggs on the flowers of the host plants (actually trees).  The egg burrows its way into the seed and tender heart of the bean.  By the time the monsoon rains come in July, they have eaten all the beans tender innards.  There are 3 beans in a pod and it is covered by a thin skin, similar to walnuts.  The trees need about 20 days to soak up enough water to cause the skin to disgorge the beans, again similar to the walnuts.  Their jumping is a survival measure.  The heat is their enemy.  They jump to escape the heat as it would dehydrate and kill them.  They search for a cool damp place to survivie until Spring.  Many years ago, the bean harvest was over 12 million beans per year.  Now it is about 1/5 that much.  The scare of infestation at the various borders has made exportation more difficult.  The pickers now are mostly senior citizens."
Sports simulation game covering the 800 meters (metres) event.

From the game rules:

"The main objective is to buy properties at auction, improve them and then sell them through estate agents. Doing this should make players a profit - and at the end of the game the most prosperous player is the winner."

Published by Casper Games Ltd, a Bristol [UK] based company - not the same as the other Casper Games.

From the West End Games online catalog.

Social Disorder a fast-paced card game designed for three to six players, simulates the uncertain world of high-school social groups. Each card represents a student in a clique, such as the Lunch-Stealer Bully, the Goth Burn-Out, and the Gamer Geek. Social Disorder combines the trick-based play of classic games such as Spades and Hearts with a twist: Each player has a hidden rule, which can affect all other players. Is the suit order reversed for this hand? Can the same player not win two tricks in a row? Can you force two players to swap hands? Only you know what your rule is, and you can choose whether or not to enforce it. And, just like high school, no one knows all the rules.

Designed by three-time Origins-Award-winner Steven Marsh, Social Disorder takes about an hour to play per game. It comes with everything you need except friends ... just like high school.

What Geek wouldn't want to explore the wonderful worlds of the late Barbara Cartland? In this game, you choose from one of 12 BC heroines. "Whether she is a rich American heiress or a poor peasant girl, you'll recognize her to be a true Barbara Cartland heroine: soft, gentle, innocent, and pure, but also intelligent, charming, and resourceful."
Players then follow the heroine in her adventures on the Mayfair Modular map using a paragraph style Adventure Book. The winner is the first to (presumably) meet her True Love, and reach her Happy Ending. "Sigh..."

A game of the World War Two amphibious invasion of Italy September 8/9, 1943.  Map sheet is black and white showing the part of Italy surrounding the Gulf of Salerno where the Allied Armies invaded the night of 8/9 September 1943.
  
Games uses zones of control and has 119 yellow (Allies) and 119 red (German, Italians) die cut unit counters.  Total counters with blanks is 238. Victory is on a point system for various objectives (such as 5 points awarded for whoever holds Montecorvino airfield at the end of the game, etc.).  Includes four page rule book and two page "correction sheet."  Very rare game from 1972.  Envelope/zip lock game.

Mouse and elephant are a little bit mixed. The first to make the pictures complete, wins.

Little pieces with parts of a puzzle are mixed in the middle of the table. Every players have to take and place the tiles with one hand. The first to finish the puzzle of the mouse and the elephant, wins.

The Wizard of Oz Returns (Game and Record)      
Sid Frank/Ralph Stein      
Golden Records

Amusing sequel to the Wizard of Oz complete with songs and voices that attempt to match the 1939 musical, but which follows neither the thread of the MGM film nor the book.

Simple Roll and Move game, significant in that game board is actually printed on a vinyl record sleeve.

Get a higher score than your opponent in nine innings. Two dice are rolled and added together, and the result is referenced on a chart. Possible results are hits (singles, doubles, triples and home runs), outs (including a double play), foul balls, and even wild pitches. Since individual strikes and balls are not included on the result chart, the game plays a bit faster.

The game includes 4 pegs for each player, two standard dice, and a pencil to keep score. This game, along with others is from Channel Craft's Vintage Game Series, and is part of the Collection of THE NEW YORK HISTORICAL SOCIETY. It is a replication of the McLoughlin Brothers game of the same name originally produced in 1901.
 It comes in a small tin. Progress is marked with pegs, which rest in holes after each play, making it a very portable game.

Be the first to score four touchdowns. Each play is determined by rolling two standard dice and finding the result on a chart. Possible results are touchdowns, gains, sacks, incompletes, interceptions, fumbles, and penalties. Some of the results require the player to flip a special wooden chip, which has a "5" on one side and a "10" on the other, and is used to randomly determine yards gained or lost.

Play is tracked on a wooden board, using pegs to mark the ball and the first down mark on the field, and the current down and number of yards to go down below. Score is kept using a pencil.

The use of pegs makes it a suitable choice for travel. This game, along with others in Channel Craft's Vintage Game Series, comes in a small tin.

A variation of "BUNCO!", but more intended for a larger crowd,  with this! There are to be '3' sets of 4-Players per 'Table' of which there are 3-kinds of these: "Low"; "Medium"; and "High", with the people sitting opposite from each other as 'Partners'. Following the more traditional 'scoring' and "round robin" procedures for "BUNCO!", while this uses '3'-Dice(d6) per 'Table'. Here's what you get for components: the "Bell"; '9'-Dice(d6) of 3-Sets of various colors; a pouch to hold the DICE; a 'Scoring' pad; the "Rules"; and the BOX for them all.

From the box:

What happens when a couple of unrelated things slam into each other? You chuckle out loud...but not 'til after you figure out what brought them together in the first place! It's always a race against time in this hysterical game where pop culture collides with silliness! Put on your helmet and buckle up - Culture Crash is a wild ride!

An example of one of the clues and answer from the box:

clue: A button beside a house entrance...meets...flared pants...

answer: Door BELL Bottoms

In the Meikyu Kingdom Card Game, each player tries to conquer dungeon cards using heroes and items selected from their hands.

Each turn, a player draws a card and then performs one of the following actions: (1) Conquer a dungeon card, (2) develop a conquered card, (3) attack a dungeon card owned by another player, (4) draw an extra card.

Conquering a dungeon card involves matching the value of the card with the "Bravery" values of adventure cards played from your hand or playing a lower value to which the value of one die roll is added.

Each dungeon card shows a star-value, and by developing a dungeon card you can double this value. The player who is first to collect a 10 star value in dungeon cards wins the game.

Six is a deceptively simple-looking abstract strategy game in which two (or four) players take turns placing their colored hexagonal tiles while trying to create one of the three "winning shapes" – triangle, hexagon or line – out of six of their tiles. If all tiles have been placed from players' hands without someone winning, players then take turns picking up a previously placed tile and moving it to a new position.

With the advanced rules, players are allowed to move a tile that will separate all the tiles into two or more groups; by doing this, some pieces are removed from the game, and this provides an alternate way to win by reducing the opponent to five or fewer pieces (as the opponent cannot possibly form a winning shape).
Flip chips at the goal cards and try to collect the most.

Translated and edited from the website of the publisher:

THE GAME
Malstrom is a exciting and artful game for two to four persons. The playing time is about half an hour. At the beginning of the game 49 cards are layed out with their face down. Therewith, the hidden cards take the function of a chessfield. The goal of the game is to collect most of the couples. It is not enough, just to remember the position of each card. It is equally important to cleverly plan ahaed your own moves.

THE CONCEPT
Malstrom is published in several editions. For each edition, a, as far as possible, well thumbed book is been used. The single pages of the book are furnished with motives. Out of these pages fragments are generated, which in pairs result in collages. The motives of the respective edition are inspired by the content, the theme, or the author of the book.

Nerved river-silicics with pores, breaches and twinkling inclusions are used as tokens in the game.

The selection of these stones is determined by respective theme and in a way that an ensemble forms. In the basic version, each Malstrom is stored within a cartridge (ca. 25 cm x 35 cm x 4 cm) of 13mm thick three-corrugated cardboard. It contains 49 cards (34 cards with motives, 15 without), four river-silicics, the rules, a copy of the impressums of the used book, the number of the respective game and a signature.

A single cards measures:   ca. 6,5 x 6,5 cm

In this game there are a game board placed vertically. On the board there five rows that you can shift pieces. And there are 26 pieces in two colour.You try to connect your color from bottom to top. In reality each row takes five piece. We can say this game is played on a 5x5 grid.
Players try to capture as many of the Gold Medals as possible and obtain the most points to win.

The object is to be the first player to land on the space where the infamous Jim Bone has hidden the gold that was removed from the 18th Century wreck in the Scilly Isles (off the tip of Cornwall, England).

A set of normal and compass dice (one die with N,E,S,W on and one die with NE,SE, NW, SW on) direct the movement.

In the first phase of the game, you each aim to collect three clue cards outlining the location of the treasure.  When one player has one of each type of clues to complete the set of three, they claim the Golden X card. The location of the treasure is now defined.

In the second phase of the game, players scramble to obtain the whereabouts of the treasure, attacking each other. The race to claim the gold is on.

From the publisher:

Tactical Duck Combat! Just what you always wanted from Tri Tac Games.

The back woods in central Pennsylvania and a quack in the night start the nightmare of the opening days of what mankind would later call "the Duck Wars". They've come from the swamps to prey on Campers and Cub Scouts. This is a crazy board game that is kind of like an RPG. Fun for the whole family as you attempt to stop the duckbilled horror.

Join the Scouts as they revenge the death of their Scout Master at the Beak of the Giant Mutated Duck.  Contains 6" X 9" Hex grid, 40 paper counters, lots of fun (beer, pretzels and other embellishments not included).

No. 1 in the Duck Trilogy

From the Introduction in the rules:

On May 10, 1869, the Union Pacific and the Central Pacific met at Promontory Summit to establish the first transcontinental railroad for the United States.  The route taken by the Union Pacific just grazed the tip of Colorado at Julesberg and headed west through Wyoming.  Colorado, however, wanted railroads and soon got them.

In the Colorado Railroads Game, players assume the roles of the big financiers who put together the rails that roamed the Rockies.  Somewhat in the tradition of Heartland Trefoil's 1829, and Avalon Hill's 1830, players buy shares of stock in various railroads, take control of them, and build track from city to city, and city to mine.  The railroads earn money by operating trains between stations.  Player money is earned through dividends to stockholders.  Unlike the above mentioned games, the rails are drawn right on the map, and owned by the railroads who built them (As in Mayfair's Empire Builder system.)  The economic conditions change varying from boom times to depression, and mines appear and disappear at random throughout the game.

This game in the KI.KA Spiel series by Kosmos uses characters from a German children's television programme, KI.KA. Chili, Briegel and Bernd are packing to go on holiday and each player is helping them to pack 15 items in their suitcases.

Each player receives a chip with the face of each of the 3 characters, and a number of tiles shaped like cards, planes and ships (modes of holiday transport) in 3 different colours (red, blue, yellow) are placed in the centre. There is a stack of rectangular card tiles showing different numbers of items one might bring on holiday (books, caps, sunglasses, slippers, etc.) and each player reveals one card. Players then place a chip on the items they would like to pack. Cards without chips are discarded, cards with only one chip are taken by the player who put the chip there, leaving cards with more than one chip on them. Ownership of the tiles with more than one chip are resolved by throwing a six-sided die showing the 3 forms of transport and the 3 colours. Players with a chip on the card being competed for now grab as many of the colour or kind of transport shown on the die - the player who grabs the most gets to keep the cards and the items on it.
The winner is the first player to pack 15 items in each of his or her 3 character's suitcases.

Splash Attack is a fast reaction game in which players must quickly react to the roll of the dice. The game comes with several chunky wooden fish in three different colors, with three of each color of fish, each having a different design on them consisting of either squares, circles, or triangles.

On each turn, someone rolls the two special dice. One die has colored faces, and the other die has shapes. Players look at the die roll and quickly grab the matching fish from the table! For example, if blue and square is rolled, you would want to grab the blue fish with squares on it.

However, if a player already has the matching fish in his play area, the players yell "Splash Attack!" and grab the red piranha. If the player that already had the matching fish is the first to do this, he gets to permanently keep the fish as a point. If a different player is quickest, however, the player loses the fish back to the center of the table. Thus, you must be the quickest to react to a matching pattern twice in a row to score. The first player to score three fish wins!
Collect all four frames of Peanuts comic strips to score points.

The game consists of seven different small games. All games are around learning the alfabet in a fun way.

You start with choosing a board each and mix all the tiles. Depending on the number of the dice you pick that 1-3 tiles from the table and see if you have that on your board. The first one to complete the board is the winner.

The different games are on different levels to keep the game challenging for children. The first level starts with easy characters, and the last level use the complete alfabet.

Alfons Åberg Lotto are two games. 
One is a game where you get a tile with Alfons Åberg figures, and you should match the tiles you turn up on the table with your tile. The first to complete the tile is the winner.

The other game is more a memory game where you should try to collect the figures that is on your tile. A mix game between memory and bingo. The one who has completed the tile first is the winner.

A new collectable miniatures game geared towards younger players (ages 8 and up).  Each player has an avatar figure which is hidden inside one of several "zypods": nesting-doll like containers which have a top and bottom half that represent different fighting creatures.  When the creature is defeated, the zypod is "cracked" so that the pod nested inside comes into play.  The game ends when one player finds the other's avatar and defeats it in combat.

The initial set will have 90 different creatures to collect, creating thousands of possible top/bottom combinations.

In this game, players explore a variable landscape to discover islands and try to gain influence and prestige. Influence is gained by taking over posts on the island which gives the player special abilities.

Expanded by Big Kini Expansion: 5-6 Players and Action Cards

Pharaoh Krimsutep has called, and his master builders have come.
You and your fellow players erect magnificent palaces, impressive obelisks and design wonderful oases for the great Pharaoh Krimsutep. You plan your designs well, but be careful to play your material procurement cards correctly. Who will win in the contest of the Pharaoh's favor?

Translation of German description:
The heads of big politics clash in their fight for power. Take over their role and show those other combatants who the real king of the hill is: use ministers, panels and the press to bully your opponents or to increase your own glory. Get your politicians into the government to create the stupidest and most senseless laws and to reserve your seat in the political cabinet of absurdities. 
First shown at Essen 2005

A quick trick taking game for two based on Triomphe (French Ruff), and played with a 32-card Piquet deck (standard playing card deck stripped of all 2-6's). Écarté has an unusual press-your-luck mechanism which allows both players to exchange cards in hand for cards in the draw deck. This exchange is by agreement, and may occur multiple times before the first trick is played.

Écarté was originally a club gambling game, with both players and spectators wagering on the winner of the best of five tricks, and the location of the king of trumps.

Stalag Luft III - The Great Escape, is Game system based on the true story of the mass breakout of Allied POWs from the German prisoner-of-war camp at Sagan in occupied Poland in 1944.

There are two versions of the game currently in progress.
The first is a table top game using a large fully detailed scale model of the camp - much like a wargame.

The second is simplified Boardgame version which is a strategy style of game.

The same 28mm (1/60th scale) metal miniatures are used for both versions of the game and are available from the Ebob Miniatures website: www.ebobminiatures.com

The rules for the table top game are still in development, however a working version of the boardgame is presented here for you to download and print out

The literal translation of the title is Sea-Land-Air Fighting Chess. This is an expanded version of Lu Zhan Jun Qi (Army Chess). Besides the soldiers featured in Lu Zhan Jun Qi, this game also features ships, planes and land features like tanks. The board also features a sea to accommodate the naval pieces.
Like Army Chess, it is a game for two players but requires a third person to act as umpire in resolving battle. The objective is to capture the opposing force's flag.

Players manuever their wrestlers in the ring an each turn can use their action points to simultaneously select a move (from the cards in hand) to try on the opponent.  The moves are cross-indexed and appropriate damage is dealt to opponent.  The match is over when one wrestler is pinned or both have accumulated 75 or more impairment points.

Promotional copy said "the only board game that comes in a can so strong that you can stand on it without it breaking!"

BIRD-OPOLY is a game based on our fabulous feathered friends. It has all the fun of a traditional property trading game with some fancy flying twists and turns. The game features backyard, rare, and favorite birds of North America and each Bird Deed is filled with fun facts about the bird. When playing the game you can choose to be, among others, a hummingbird, a birdbath, or a pair of binoculars! Trade your bird houses in for a big tree and you’ll be the big winner in Bird-opoly! Game play is for 2-6 players, ages 8 and up.

Diaballik is an abstract strategy game for 2 players. The game attempts to simulate a sport whereby 2 teams are simultaneously trying to get their ball to the opposite teams starting goal line.

The board depicts a 7×7 grid. Each player starts with 7 ball holders along their edge of the board and their ball in the middle holder. Players subsequently take turns completing the following actions:


     Moving an empty ball holder orthogonally (up to 2 times); and/or
     Making a ball "pass" by moving the ball from on holder to another along lateral (horizontal) or diagonal line. Pass are not limited in length as long as no opponent pieces are in the way.


First person to send their teams ball to a holder on the opponents starting line wins. It's worth noting that an impenetrable wall of ball holders results in an automatic loss to the player who created the wall.

Nominated for the 2006 As d'Or Game of the Year.

Online Play


     BoÃ®te Ã  jeux (turn-based)


Available on iPad (via iTunes Apps Store) since the june 21st 2011 (2 players local game, or 1 player vs AI)

Strategiespiel nach den Prinzipien von Mannschaftssportarten, mit Bewegung und Pässen. Ziel des Spiels ist es seine Kugel auf die Startlinie des Gegners zu bringen.  Um dies zu erreichen muss jeder Spieler Angriffe und Verteidigungen spielen. Hinter einem einfachen Mechanismus verbirgt sich ein dynamisches Strategiespiel, welches bis zum letzten Augenblick spannend bleibt, da überraschende Wendungen immer möglich sind.

Giseh Verlag
Goal of this fun card game is to park in the city center without getting a ticket.

Chef de bataillon introduces you to the exciting world of tactical warfare in the Napoleonic period. Especially designed for use with historical miniatures, Chef de bataillon places you in command of the units of history’s most colorful and heroic era. You are the Chef de bataillon, in command of a infantry battalion, cavalry regiment, or a battery of artillery.

Battalion and regimental officers, as well as command personalities are incorporated into Chef de bataillon’s unique rules system. Battles may be played with miniatures in any range from 5mm to 25mm. Chef de bataillon is so flexible it allows you to play tactical level battles throughout the entire horse and musket era.

In Chef de bataillon, battle is quick and dangerous. Created by the award-winning designers of Empire, Chef de bataillon is easy to learn, fast moving, and exciting to play. In addition Chef de bataillon scenarios allow you to jump into battle right away!

Discover the challenge and excitement of true tactical warfare in the Napoleonic era. Discover the most original approach in miniatures wargaming. Discover Chef de bataillon - you can almost smell the powder smoke!

Chef de bataillon contains: 
A 196 page rule set;
a set of 65 pages of ratings, data and scenarios;
20 quick reference charts; and
2 die cut counter sheets.

Chef de bataillon brings to life the capabilities of troops and weapons and the effects of terrain in a new and innovative way. But most importantly, Chef de bataillon places you at the head of the troops. You must provide the leadership!  You must master the art of war at the tactical level! You must find the bravery to lead your formation into the very mouths of the guns for victory and glory!

(source: Emperor's press website)

It's Game Time, Let's Roll! ™

Now with GRIDDLE!QuickPlay option: A complete game in just 30 minutes!!!

American Football meets Backgammon! ™

GRIDDLE! is an intriguing, fast-paced, 2-player game for anyone who enjoys Backgammon (and other strategically similar games), where you weigh the odds, as well as your opponent's style of play, when deciding how to execute each roll of the dice.

Throw in a unique time management system, along with an American Football theme, and you've got a clean, crisp, "non-sports" game of strategy and chance that doesn't bog down in the tediousness of endless chart referencing!

Although no knowledge or terminology of American Football is necessary, the GRIDDLE! experience will satisfy both the "sports" and "non-sports" gamer in everyone!

The Challenge:
Outscore your opponent by balancing offensive and defensive strategy, while managing time and the probabilities presented with every roll of the dice!

The Contents:
1 - GRIDDLE!Stadium Gameboard
8 - Scoreboard Markers
5 - Dual-color Game Pieces (Gridders)
1 - Set of 5 Dice w/ Dots
1 - Set of 5 Dice w/ Digits
1 - Plastic Coin
1 - GRIDDLE!Rules Booklet
     (with GRIDDLE!QuickPlay)

Players: 2
Ages: 7 to Adult
Playing Time: 1 Hour (1/2 hour using GRIDDLE!QuickPlay option)

This game is a fun way to enjoy Sudoku with a friend!

First, put in the "starter" numbers from one of the 100 cards using the green disks. Now agree how many one minute turns you will both take and who will start - then off you go.

It's a nail biting race to get as many correct numbers in YOUR colour as possible, during the agreed number of turns. Score for every correct number, but beware - wrong numbers are subtracted from your total.

The red filter allows for extra clues and lets better players take on less practiced friends.

In Carol's own words -

"I am a Sudoku addict. It seems that Sudoku addicts are male, female, young and old. We are all hooked. This game is the next stage of the Sudoku craze - it allows players of different levels to compete fairly against each other. I love it - it's perfect for all the family and fantastic value for the money"
Carol Vorderman

"It's beginning to look a lot like Christmas! Christmas in-a-Box is a game filled with all the things that make Christmas the best time of year. Buy properties such as Christmas Cookies, Mistletoe, Sleigh Ride, Fruit Cake, or Lump of Coal. Be good or you may be sent to Naughty or end up with a Scrooge Fine! Land on Santa Claus and collect everything in the center of the board! Christmas in-a-Box is sure to bring family and friends together for a jolly good time. Perfect for family get-togethers or holiday gift giving.
Ages 8 and up for 2 to 6 players."

"Christmas-in-a-Box" was also released in 2004 as "'Twas the Night Before Christmas" with a different board, but the game remains the same: a strict Monopoly clone.

Each Player is a druid, trying to become the leader of all druids by mixing magic potions out of herb-cards and using the powers of celtic gods. "Merlins Erben" was the last game published by Salagames and was republished 1995 by Hexagames with modified rules as "Die Druiden".

From the publisher's Web site: Let Leonardo be your guide to the secrets of the ancient world and the great achievements of civilization. In this new trivia game, follow the path of the famed Templar Knights as you journey across five continents in your quest to crack a mysterious "code word." Each correct answer to one of 100s of multiple choice trivia questions reveals a new clue to the "code word." Categories consist of Genius and the Grail, People and Places, Faith and Fable, and Quest Curiosities. 
Players are dealt five cards, face up and one, face down. Each card features a word and a letter. The word on the face down card is a player's "code word." As players move around the board answering the multiple choice trivia questions, they are afforded the opportunity to trade and/or "steal" oppponents' or supply stack letter cards to replace their own stack of 5, face up cards, in a quest to form the "code word." Once players have formed their "code word" with their 5, face-up cards, they proceed to a central (Grail) square and attempt to answer a final question to win the game and complete their quest.
